newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft buys Internet firm VXtreme.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft buys Internet firm VXtreme.

text.p: Microsoft Corp said Tuesday it has acquired VXtreme Inc., a Silicon Valley developer of technology for sending audio and video over the Internet.
Terms were not disclosed, although a source familiar with the deal put the value at $75 million.

Microsoft said VXtreme's technology for compressing and audio and video and "streaming" it for continuous delivery over the Internet would be integrated into future versions of its NetShow and Site Server products.

VXtreme, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., was founded last year by Stanford University computer scientists and funded by investors including Cisco Systems Inc, Softbank Corp of Japan and Informix Software.
Microsoft also announced the release of its NetShow 2.0 streaming media server.

Microsoft said the acquisition of VXtreme, as well as last month's investment in Seattle-based Progressive Networks Inc., are part of a push to expand the market and win acceptance of its Active Streaming Format.
Several other Internet companies said they were backing the Microsoft effort.
AudioNet, which calls itself the largest broadcast network on the Internet, said it launched the NetShow network to showcase the Microsoft technology.
And Microsoft said Vivo Software Inc has agreed to base its broadcast tool product line on Microsoft technology.
